Heading: 1850s[edit]
List Text: 1856: Alexander Parkes invents parkesine , also known as celluloid , the first man-made plastic .

Heading: 1850s[edit]
List Text: 1856: James Harrison produces the world's first practical ice making machine and refrigerator using the principle of vapour compression in Geelong, Australia. [403]

Heading: 1850s[edit]
List Text: 1856: William Henry Perkin invents mauveine , the first synthetic dye .

Heading: 1850s[edit]
List Text: 1857: Heinrich Geissler invents the Geissler tube .

Heading: 1850s[edit]
List Text: 1857: The phonautograph , the earliest known device for recording sound is patented and invented by Frenchman Édouard-Léon Scott de Martinville .

Heading: 1850s[edit]
List Text: 1859: Gaston Planté invents the lead acid battery , the first rechargeable battery .

Heading: 1860s[edit]
List Text: 1860: Joseph Swan produces carbon fibers . [404]

Heading: 1860s[edit]
List Text: 1864: Louis Pasteur invents the pasteurization process.

Heading: 1860s[edit]
List Text: 1865: Carl Wilhelm Siemens and Pierre-Émile Martin invented the Siemens-Martin process for making steel.

Heading: 1860s[edit]
List Text: 1867: Alfred Nobel invents dynamite , the first safely manageable explosive stronger than black powder .

Heading: 1860s[edit]
List Text: 1867: Lucien B. Smith invents barbed wire , which Joseph F. Glidden will modify in 1874, leading to the taming of the West and the end of the cowboys.

Heading: 1870s[edit]
List Text: 1872: Polyvinyl chloride , more commonly known as vinyl, is synthesized by German chemist Eugen Baumann

Heading: 1870s[edit]
List Text: 1872: J.E.T. Woods and J. Clark invented stainless steel . Harry Brearley was the first to commercialize it. [405]

Heading: 1870s[edit]
List Text: 1873: Frederick Ransome invents the rotary kiln .

Heading: 1870s[edit]
List Text: 1873: William Crookes , a chemist, invents the Crookes radiometer as the by-product of some chemical research.

Heading: 1870s[edit]
List Text: 1873: Zénobe Gramme invents the first commercial electrical generator , the Gramme machine .

Heading: 1870s[edit]
List Text: 1874: Gustave Trouvé invents the first metal detector .

Heading: 1870s[edit]
List Text: 1875: Fyodor Pirotsky invents the first electric tram near Saint Petersburg, Russia .

Heading: 1870s[edit]
List Text: 1876: Nicolaus August Otto invents the four-stroke cycle .

Heading: 1870s[edit]
List Text: 1876: Alexander Graham Bell has a patent granted for the telephone . However, other inventors before Bell had worked on the development of the telephone and the invention had several pioneers. [406]

Heading: 1870s[edit]
List Text: 1877: Thomas Edison invents the first working phonograph . [407]

Heading: 1870s[edit]
List Text: 1878: Henry Fleuss is granted a patent for the first practical rebreather . [408]

Heading: 1870s[edit]
List Text: 1878: Lester Allan Pelton invents the Pelton wheel .

Heading: 1870s[edit]
List Text: 1879: Joseph Swan and Thomas Edison both patent a functional incandescent light bulb . Some two dozen inventors had experimented with electric incandescent lighting over the first three-quarters of the 19th century but never came up with a practical design. [409] Swan's, which he had been working on since the 1860s, had a low resistance so was only suited for small installations. Edison designed a high-resistance bulb as part of a large-scale commercial electric lighting utility. [410] [411] [412]

Heading: 1880s[edit]
List Text: 1881: Nikolay Benardos presents carbon arc welding , the first practical arc welding method. [413]

Heading: 1880s[edit]
List Text: 1884: Hiram Maxim invents the recoil-operated Maxim gun , ushering in the age of semi- and fully automatic firearms.

Heading: 1880s[edit]
List Text: 1884: Paul Vieille invents Poudre B , the first smokeless powder for firearms.

Heading: 1880s[edit]
List Text: 1884: Sir Charles Parsons invents the modern steam turbine .

Heading: 1880s[edit]
List Text: 1884: Hungarian engineers Károly Zipernowsky , Ottó Bláthy and Miksa Déri invent the closed core high efficiency transformer and the AC parallel power distribution.

Heading: 1880s[edit]
List Text: 1885: John Kemp Starley invents the modern safety bicycle . [414] [415]

Heading: 1880s[edit]
List Text: 1886: Carl Gassner invents the zinc–carbon battery , the first dry cell battery , making portable electronics practical.

Heading: 1880s[edit]
List Text: 1886: Charles Martin Hall and independently Paul Héroult invent the Hall–Héroult process for economically producing aluminum in 1886.

Heading: 1880s[edit]
List Text: 1886: Karl Benz invents the first petrol or gasoline powered auto-mobile (car). [416]

Heading: 1880s[edit]
List Text: 1887: Carl Josef Bayer invents the Bayer process for the production of alumina.

Heading: 1880s[edit]
List Text: 1887: James Blyth invents the first wind turbine used for generating electricity.

Heading: 1880s[edit]
List Text: 1887: John Stewart MacArthur , working in collaboration with brothers Dr. Robert and Dr. William Forrest develops the process of gold cyanidation .

Heading: 1880s[edit]
List Text: 1888: John J. Loud invents the ballpoint pen . [417]

Heading: 1880s[edit]
List Text: 1888: Thomas Edison and William Kennedy Dickson invents Kinetoscope . [418]

Heading: 1880s[edit]
List Text: 1888: Heinrich Hertz publishes a conclusive proof of James Clerk Maxwell 's electromagnetic theory in experiments that also demonstrate the existence of radio waves . The effects of electromagnetic waves had been observed by many people before this but no usable theory explaining them existed until Maxwell.

Heading: 1880s[edit]
List Text: 1888: The first practical pneumatic tire was made by Scotsman John Boyd Dunlop , the patent was from 1847 by Robert William Thomson

Heading: 1890s[edit]
List Text: 1890s: Frédéric Swarts invents the first chlorofluorocarbons to be applied as refrigerant. [419]

Heading: 1890s[edit]
List Text: 1890: Robert Gair would invent the pre-cut cardboard box . [420]

Heading: 1890s[edit]
List Text: 1891: Whitcomb Judson invents the zipper .

Heading: 1890s[edit]
List Text: 1892: Léon Bouly invents the cinematograph .

Heading: 1890s[edit]
List Text: 1892: Thomas Ahearn invents the electric oven . [421]

Heading: 1890s[edit]
List Text: 1893: Rudolf Diesel invents the diesel engine (although Herbert Akroyd Stuart had experimented with compression ignition before Diesel).

Heading: 1890s[edit]
List Text: 1893: William Stewart Halsted , invents the rubber glove for his wife Caroline Hampton as he noticed her hands were affected on the daily surgeries she had performed and in order to prevent medical staff from developing dermatitis from surgical chemicals. [422] [423] [424] The first modern disposable glove was invented by Ansell Rubber Co. Pty. Ltd. in 1965. [425] [426] [427]

Heading: 1890s[edit]
List Text: 1895: Guglielmo Marconi invents a system of wireless communication using radio waves.

Heading: 1890s[edit]
List Text: 1895: Wilhelm Conrad Röntgen invented the first radiograph (xrays).

Heading: 1890s[edit]
List Text: 1897: Surgical masks made of cloth were developed in Europe by physicians Jan Mikulicz-Radecki at the University of Breslau and Paul Berger in Paris, as a result of increasing awareness of germ theory and the importance of antiseptic procedures in medicine. [428]

Heading: 1890s[edit]
List Text: 1898: Hans von Pechmann synthesizes polyethylene , now the most common plastic in the world. [429]

Heading: 1890s[edit]
List Text: 1899: Waldemar Jungner invents the rechargeable nickel-cadmium battery (NiCd) as well as the nickel-iron electric storage battery (NiFe) and the rechargeable alkaline silver-cadmium battery (AgCd)

Heading: 20th century[edit]
List Text: 1900: The first Zeppelin is designed by Theodor Kober .

Heading: 20th century[edit]
List Text: 1901: The first motorized cleaner using suction, a powered " vacuum cleaner ", is patented independently by Hubert Cecil Booth and David T. Kenney . [430]

Heading: 20th century[edit]
List Text: 1903: The first successful gas turbine is invented by Ægidius Elling .

Heading: 20th century[edit]
List Text: 1903: Édouard Bénédictus invents laminated glass .

Heading: 20th century[edit]
List Text: 1903: First sustained and controlled heavier-than-air powered flight achieved by an airplane flown at Kitty Hawk, North Carolina by Orville and Wilbur Wright . See Claims to the first powered flight .

Heading: 20th century[edit]
List Text: 1904: The Fleming valve , the first vacuum tube and diode , is invented by John Ambrose Fleming .

List Text: 1907: The first free flight of a rotary-wing aircraft is carried out by Paul Cornu .

List Text: 1907: Leo Baekeland invents bakelite ,  the first plastic made from synthetic components.

Heading: 1910s[edit]
List Text: 1911: The cloud chamber , the first particle detector , is invented by Charles Thomson Rees Wilson .

Heading: 1910s[edit]
List Text: 1912: The first commercial slot cars or more accurately model electric racing cars operating under constant power were made by Lionel (USA) and appeared in their catalogues in 1912. They drew power from a toy train rail sunk in a trough that was connected to a battery.

Heading: 1910s[edit]
List Text: 1912: The first use of articulated trams by Boston Elevated Railway .

Heading: 1910s[edit]
List Text: 1913: The Bergius process is developed by Friedrich Bergius .

Heading: 1910s[edit]
List Text: 1913: The Kaplan turbine is invented by Viktor Kaplan .

Heading: 1910s[edit]
List Text: 1915: Harry Brearley invents a process to create Martensitic stainless steel , initially labelled Rustless Steel, later marketed as Staybrite, and AISI Type 420. [437]

Heading: 1910s[edit]
List Text: 1915: The first operational military tanks are designed in Great Britain and France. They are used in battle from 1916 and 1917 respectively. The designers in Great Britain are Walter Wilson and William Tritton and in France, Eugène Brillié . (Although it is known that vehicles incorporating at least some of the features of the tank were designed in a number of countries from 1903 onward, none reached a practical form.)

Heading: 1910s[edit]
List Text: 1916: The Czochralski process , widely used for the production of single crystal silicon , is invented by Jan Czochralski .

Heading: 1910s[edit]
List Text: 1917: The crystal oscillator is invented by Alexander M. Nicholson using a crystal of Rochelle Salt although his priority was disputed by Walter Guyton Cady .

Heading: 1920s[edit]
List Text: 1925: The Fischer–Tropsch process is developed by Franz Fischer and Hans Tropsch at the Kaiser-Wilhelm-Institut für Kohlenforschung .

Heading: 1920s[edit]
List Text: 1926: The Yagi-Uda Antenna or simply Yagi Antenna is invented by Shintaro Uda of Tohoku Imperial University , assisted by his colleague Hidetsugu Yagi . The Yagi Antenna was widely used during World War II . After the war they saw extensive development as home television antennas .

Heading: 1920s[edit]
List Text: 1926: Robert H. Goddard launches the first liquid fueled rocket .

Heading: 1920s[edit]
List Text: 1926: Harry Ferguson , patents the Three-point hitch equipment linkage system for tractors. [438]

Heading: 1920s[edit]
List Text: 1926: John Logie Baird demonstrates the world's first live working television system. [439] [440] [441]

Heading: 1920s[edit]
List Text: 1927: The quartz clock is invented by Warren Marrison and J.W. Horton at Bell Telephone Laboratories . [442]

Heading: 1920s[edit]
List Text: 1928: Penicillin is first observed to exude antibiotic substances by Nobel laureate Alexander Fleming . Development of medicinal penicillin is attributed to a team of medics and scientists including Howard Walter Florey , Ernst Chain and Norman Heatley .

Heading: 1920s[edit]
List Text: 1928: Frank Whittle formally submitted his ideas for a turbo-jet engine. In October 1929, he developed his ideas further. [443] On 16 January 1930, Whittle submitted his first patent (granted in 1932). [444] [445]

Heading: 1920s[edit]
List Text: 1928: Philo Farnsworth demonstrates the first practical electronic television to the press.

Heading: 1920s[edit]
List Text: 1929: The ball screw is invented by Rudolph G. Boehm.

Heading: 1930s[edit]
List Text: 1930: The Supersonic combusting ramjet — Frank Whittle . [446]

Heading: 1930s[edit]
List Text: 1930: The Phase-contrast microscopy is invented by Frits Zernike .

Heading: 1930s[edit]
List Text: 1931: The electron microscope is invented by Ernst Ruska .

Heading: 1930s[edit]
List Text: 1933: FM radio is patented by inventor Edwin H. Armstrong .

Heading: 1930s[edit]
List Text: 1933: Harry C. Jennings Sr. and his disabled friend Herbert Everest , both mechanical engineers , invented the first lightweight, steel, folding, portable wheelchair with their "X-brace" design. [447] [448]

Heading: 1930s[edit]
List Text: 1935: Nylon , the first fully synthetic fiber is produced by Wallace Carothers while working at DuPont . [449]

Heading: 1930s[edit]
List Text: 1938: Z1 , built by Konrad Zuse , is the first freely programmable computer in the world.

Heading: 1930s[edit]
List Text: 1938: Nuclear fission discovered in experiment by chemists Otto Hahn and Fritz Strassmann and physicists Lise Meitner and Otto Robert Frisch . The German nuclear energy project was based on this research. The Tube Alloys project and, subsequently, the Manhattan Project and the Soviet atomic bomb project were influenced by this research.

Heading: 1930s[edit]
List Text: 1939: G. S. Yunyev or Naum Gurvich invented the electric current defibrillator

Heading: 1940s[edit]
List Text: 1940: Pu-239 isotope (isotope of plutonium ) [450] [451] a form of matter existing with the capacity for use as a destructive element [452] (because the isotope has an exponentially increasing [450] spontaneous [453] fissile decay [454] ) within nuclear devices — Glenn Seaborg . [451]

Heading: 1940s[edit]
List Text: 1940: John Randall and Harry Boot would develop the high power, microwave generating, cavity magnetron , later applied to commercial Radar and Microwave oven appliances. [455]

Heading: 1940s[edit]
List Text: 1941: Polyester is invented by John Rex Whinfield and James Dickson. [456]

Heading: 1940s[edit]
List Text: 1942: The V-2 rocket , the world's first long range ballistic missile , developed by engineer Wernher von Braun .

Heading: 1940s[edit]
List Text: 1944: The non-infectious viral vaccine is perfected by Dr. Jonas Salk and Thomas Francis. [457]

Heading: 1940s[edit]
List Text: 1945: The atomic bomb is developed by the Manhattan Project and swiftly deployed in August 1945 in the atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki , effectively ending World War II .

Heading: 1940s[edit]
List Text: 1945: Percy Spencer , while employed at Raytheon , would patent a magnetron based microwave oven . [458]

Heading: 1940s[edit]
List Text: 1945: Willard Libby began his work on radiocarbon dating . He published his paper in 1946, [459] [460] a second paper in Science in 1947. [459] [461] Libby and James Arnold succeeded with the radiocarbon dating theory after results were published in Science in December 1949. [462] [463]

Heading: 1940s[edit]
List Text: 1946: James Martin invents the ejector seat , inspired by the death of his friend and test pilot Captain Valentine Baker in an aeroplane crash in 1942.

Heading: 1940s[edit]
List Text: 1947: Holography is invented by Dennis Gabor .

Heading: 1940s[edit]
List Text: 1947: Floyd Farris and J.B. Clark ( Stanolind Oil and Gas Corporation ) invents hydraulic fracturing technology. [464]

Heading: 1940s[edit]
List Text: 1947: The first transistor , a bipolar point-contact transistor , is invented by John Bardeen and Walter Brattain under the supervision of William Shockley at Bell Labs .

Heading: 1940s[edit]
List Text: 1948: The first atomic clock is developed at the National Bureau of Standards .

Heading: 1940s[edit]
List Text: 1948: Basic oxygen steelmaking is developed by Robert Durrer . The vast majority of steel manufactured in the world is produced using the basic oxygen furnace; in 2000, it accounted for 60% of global steel output. [465]

Heading: 1950s[edit]
List Text: 1950: Bertie the Brain , debatably the first video game , is displayed to the public at the Canadian National Exhibition .

Heading: 1950s[edit]
List Text: 1950: The Toroidal chamber with axial magnetic fields (the Tokamak ) is developed by Igor E. Tamm and Andrei D. Sakharov . [466]

Heading: 1950s[edit]
List Text: 1952: The float glass process is developed by Alastair Pilkington . [467]

Heading: 1950s[edit]
List Text: 1952: The first thermonuclear weapon is developed.

Heading: 1950s[edit]
List Text: 1953: The first video tape recorder , a helical scan recorder, is invented by Norikazu Sawazaki.

Heading: 1950s[edit]
List Text: 1954: Invention of the solar battery by Bell Telephone scientists, Calvin Souther Fuller , Daryl Chapin and Gerald Pearson capturing the Sun's power. First practical means of collecting energy from the Sun and turning it into a current of electricity.

Heading: 1950s[edit]
List Text: 1955: The hovercraft is patented by Christopher Cockerell .

Heading: 1950s[edit]
List Text: 1955: The intermodal container is developed by Malcom McLean .

Heading: 1950s[edit]
List Text: 1956: The hard disk drive is invented by IBM . [468]

Heading: 1950s[edit]
List Text: 1956: The Logic Theorist computer program, the first "artificial intelligence program", was written and invented by Allen Newell , Herbert A. Simon , and Cliff Shaw . [469]

Heading: 1950s[edit]
List Text: 1957: The laser and optical amplifier are invented and named by Gordon Gould and Charles Townes . The laser and optical amplifier are foundational to powering the Internet . [470]

Heading: 1950s[edit]
List Text: 1957: The first personal computer used by one person and controlled by a keyboard, the IBM 610 , is invented in 1957 by IBM .

Heading: 1950s[edit]
List Text: 1957: The first artificial satellite , Sputnik 1 , is launched.

Heading: 1950s[edit]
List Text: 1958 – 1959: The integrated circuit is independently invented by Jack Kilby and Robert Noyce .

Heading: 1950s[edit]
List Text: 1959: The MOSFET (MOS transistor) is invented by the Egyptian Mohamed Atalla and the Korean Dawon Kahng at Bell Labs. It is used in almost all modern electronic products . It was smaller, faster, more reliable and cheaper to manufacture than earlier bipolar transistors, leading to a revolution in computers, controls and communication. [471] [472] [473]

Heading: 1960s[edit]
List Text: 1960: The first functioning laser is invented by Theodore Maiman .

Heading: 1960s[edit]
List Text: 1963: The first electronic cigarette is created by Herbert A. Gilbert. Hon Lik is often credited with its invention as he developed the modern electronic cigarette and was the first to commercialize it.

Heading: 1960s[edit]
List Text: 1964: Shinkansen , the first high-speed rail commercial passenger service.

Heading: 1960s[edit]
List Text: 1965: Kevlar is invented by Stephanie Kwolek at DuPont .

Heading: 1960s[edit]
List Text: 1969: ARPANET and the NPL network implement packet switching , [474] [475] drawing on the concepts and designs of Donald Davies , [476] [477] and Paul Baran . [478]

Heading: 1970s[edit]
List Text: 1970s: Public-key cryptography is invented and developed by James H. Ellis , Clifford Cocks , Malcolm J. Williamson , Whitfield Diffie , Martin Hellman , Ralph Merkle , Ron Rivest , Adi Shamir , Leonard Adleman , et al.

Heading: 1970s[edit]
List Text: 1970: The pocket calculator is invented.

Heading: 1970s[edit]
List Text: 1971: The first single-chip microprocessor , the Intel 4004 , is invented. Its development was led by Federico Faggin , using his silicon-gate MOS technology. This led to the personal computer (PC) revolution. [479]

Heading: 1970s[edit]
List Text: 1971: The first space station , Salyut 1 , is launched.

Heading: 1970s[edit]
List Text: 1972: The first video game console , used primarily for playing video games on a TV, is the Magnavox Odyssey . [480]

Heading: 1970s[edit]
List Text: 1973: The first fiber optic communication systems were developed by Optelecom . [481]

Heading: 1970s[edit]
List Text: 1973: The first commercial graphical user interface is introduced in 1973 on the Xerox Alto . The modern GUI is later popularized by the Xerox Star and Apple Lisa .

Heading: 1970s[edit]
List Text: 1973: The first capacitive touchscreen is developed at CERN .

Heading: 1970s[edit]
List Text: 1974: The Transmission Control Program is proposed by Vinton Cerf and Robert E. Kahn , building on the work of Louis Pouzin , creating the basis for the modern Internet . [482] [483]

Heading: 1970s[edit]
List Text: 1974: The lithium-ion battery is invented by M. Stanley Whittingham , and further developed in the 1980s and 1990s by John B. Goodenough , Rachid Yazami and Akira Yoshino . It has impacted modern consumer electronics and electric vehicles . [484]

Heading: 1970s[edit]
List Text: 1974: The Rubik’s cube is invented by Ernő Rubik which went on the be the best selling puzzle ever.

Heading: 1970s[edit]
List Text: 1977: Dr Walter Gilbert and Frederick Sanger invented a new DNA sequencing method for which they won the Nobel Prize . [485]

Heading: 1970s[edit]
List Text: 1977: The first self-driving car that did not rely upon rails or wires under the road is designed by the Tsukuba Mechanical Engineering Laboratory. [486]

Heading: 1970s[edit]
List Text: 1978: The Global Positioning System (GPS) enters service. While not the first Satellite navigation system, it is the first to enter widespread civilian use.

Heading: 1970s[edit]
List Text: 1979: The first handheld game console with interchangeable game cartridges, the Microvision is released.

Heading: 1970s[edit]
List Text: 1979: Public dialup information, messaging and e-commerce services, were pioneered through CompuServe and RadioShack 's MicroNET, and the UK's Post Office Telecommunications Prestel services. [487] [488]

Heading: 1980s[edit]
List Text: 1980: Flash memory (both NOR and NAND types) is invented by Fujio Masuoka while working for Toshiba . It is formally introduced to the public in 1984.

Heading: 1980s[edit]
List Text: 1981: The first reusable spacecraft, the Space Shuttle undergoes test flights ahead of full operation in 1982.

Heading: 1980s[edit]
List Text: 1981: Kane Kramer develops the credit card sized, IXI digital media player . [489]

Heading: 1980s[edit]
List Text: 1982: A CD-ROM contains data accessible to, but not writable by, a computer for data storage and music playback. The 1985 Yellow Book standard developed by Sony and Philips adapted the format to hold any form of binary data . [490]

Heading: 1980s[edit]
List Text: 1982: Direct to home satellite television transmission, with the launch of Sky One service. [491]

Heading: 1980s[edit]
List Text: 1982: The first laptop computer is launched, the 8/16-bit Epson HX-20 . [492]

Heading: 1980s[edit]
List Text: 1983: Stereolithography is invented by Chuck Hull . [493]

Heading: 1980s[edit]
List Text: 1984: The first commercially available cell phone , the DynaTAC 8000X, is created by Motorola .

Heading: 1980s[edit]
List Text: 1984: DNA profiling is pioneered by Alec Jeffreys . [494] [495]

Heading: 1980s[edit]
List Text: 1989: Karlheinz Brandenburg would publish the audio compression algorithms that would be standardised as the: MPEG-1, layer 3 ( mp3 ), and later the MPEG-2, layer 7 Advanced Audio Compression (AAC). [496]

Heading: 1980s[edit]
List Text: 1989: The World Wide Web is invented by computer scientist Tim Berners-Lee . [497] [498]

Heading: 1990s[edit]
List Text: 1990: The Neo Geo AES becomes the first video game system to launch that used Memory Cards

Heading: 1990s[edit]
List Text: 1990: The first search engine invented was “ Archie ”, created by Alan Emtage a student at McGill University in Montreal

Heading: 1990s[edit]
List Text: 1991: The first commercial flash-based solid-state drive is launched by SunDisk . [499]

Heading: 1990s[edit]
List Text: 1991: The first sim card is developed by Munich smart-card maker Giesecke & Devrient,

Heading: 1990s[edit]
List Text: 1993: IBM created the first mobile app with SIMON, it had 10 bulit-in apps from Email to Calendar

Heading: 1990s[edit]
List Text: 1994: IBM Simon , World's first smartphone is developed by IBM .

Heading: 1990s[edit]
List Text: 1994: First generation of Bluetooth is developed by Ericsson Mobile . A form of data communication on short distances between electronic devices.

Heading: 1990s[edit]
List Text: 1994: A Tetris variant on the Hagenuk MT-2000 device becomes the first mobile game

Heading: 1990s[edit]
List Text: 1995: DVD is an optical disc storage format, invented and developed by Philips , Sony , Toshiba , and Panasonic in 1995. DVDs offer higher storage capacity than compact discs while having the same dimensions.

Heading: 1990s[edit]
List Text: 1995: Match.com launches as the first dating site ever and is the number 1 most visited dating site in the US

Heading: 1990s[edit]
List Text: 1995: Waiter.com launches as the first online food ordering service

Heading: 1990s[edit]
List Text: 1996: Ciena deploys the first commercial wave division multiplexing system in partnership with Sprint . This created the massive capacity of the internet. [500]

Heading: 1990s[edit]
List Text: 1996: Mobile web was first commercially offered in Finland on the Nokia 9000 Communicator phone and it was also the first phone with texting

Heading: 1990s[edit]
List Text: 1996: Bolt and Six Degrees (1997) both become the first social media sites

Heading: 1990s[edit]
List Text: 1997: The first weblog, a discussion or informational website, is created by Jorn Barger , later shortened to "blog" in 1999 by Peter Merholz.

Heading: 1990s[edit]
List Text: 1998: The first portable MP3 player is released by SaeHan Information Systems.

Heading: 1990s[edit]
List Text: 1999: The first digital video recorder (DVR), the TiVo , is launched by Xperi .

Heading: 1990s[edit]
List Text: 1999: NTT DoCoMo launches i-mode , the first integrated Online App store for mobile phones

Heading: 21st century[edit]
List Text: 2000: Sony develops the first prototypes for the Blu-ray optical disc format. The first prototype player was released in 2004.

Heading: 21st century[edit]
List Text: 2000: First documented placement of Geocaching , an outdoor recreational activity, in which participants use a Global Positioning System (GPS) receiver or mobile device and other navigational techniques to hide and seek containers, took place on May 3, 2000, by Dave Ulmer of Beavercreek, Oregon .

Heading: 21st century[edit]
